item.forgero.head: Head
book.forgero.guidebook.name: Artifica
book.forgero.guidebook.landing.about_thi:
The Artifica aims to help you on your playthrough of Forgero. It gives you the basics on how to create your first tool, schematics and how use them. After that it also gives some info on how to upgrade and modify your tool! 
\
\
[#](FF0000)*Everything is WIP*[#]()
If you run into trouble, find bugs, wanna help develop or just want to ask some questions, please join our [Discord!](https://discord.gg/3vK7ZwEDex)
book.forgero.guidebook.getting_started.i:
Hello Future Blacksmith! The world of Forgero is one of exploration, gathering and crafting. 
\
\
In this world actually collecting every material has a purpose!

The basics of Forgero are not the same as normal minecraft. To get started, making use of the Artifica is essential. 
\
\
[#](FF0000)*Please follow this handbook closely and keep it on you at all times.*[#]()
book.forgero.guidebook.getting_started.c:
You want to create your first tool. Just like in vanilla Forgero's wooden tools can be crafted with, of course, wood. 
\
\
No need for anything fancy (yet).
Forgero's tools always consist of (atleast) two parts. A [#](04bcb6)Handle[#]() and a [#](5100FF)Toolhead[#]() or a [#](5100FF)Swordblade[#]().
book.forgero.guidebook.getting_started.h:
A [#](04bcb6)Handle[#]() is needed to give your player something to hold on.  
\
\
Handles in Forgero can be upgraded later on.

The type of [#](5100FF)Toolhead[#]() you use decides which tool it is gonna be. 
\
\
So an axehead makes an axe, and a pickaxehead a pickaxe.
book.forgero.guidebook.getting_started.y:
Now we have the parts we needed to craft your first Forgero tool! 
\
\
You've always got to start somewhere, right?

Here is a small reminder for the crafting recipe. 
\
\
Now you will never forget it!
book.forgero.guidebook.schematics.schema:
Getting stone tools is a bit different than wooden ones. You will need [#](37bf00)schematics[#](). Luckily the base ones can be crafted pretty easily. 
\
\
Create new wooden parts or use the [#](7C00FF)[Disassembly Station](entry://schematics/disassembly_station)[#]().
book.forgero.guidebook.schematics.using_:
If u followed the process until now you should have some [#](37bf00)schematics[#]().
\
\
Only thing left is to find the material you wanna use!
book.forgero.guidebook.schematics.disass:
The [#](7C00FF)Disassembly Station[#]() lets you disassemble your [#](000CFF)tools[#](). This makes it possible to get back used materials or parts.
\
\
So no need to discard those old [#](000CFF)tools[#]()!

To use it you put in a [#](000CFF)tool[#]() on the left side. On the right side it will show what you get back.
\
\
[#](FF0000)*Keep in mind that not all the materials are given back.*[#]()
book.forgero.guidebook.schematics.schema:
The [#](37bf00)base schematics[#]() that you can craft yourself replicate minecraft's vanilla tools.
\
\
As the name suggest [#](37bf00)base schematics[#]() don't give your tools any additional stats or more [#](FF00C5)slots[#]().

There are more [#](37bf00)schematics[#]() than just the base ones. Higher tier [#](37bf00)schematics[#]() have stat boosts or special abilities such as vein mining. These [#](37bf00)schematics[#]() cannot be crafted, and must be acquired via alternative means.
book.forgero.guidebook.schematics.refine:
[#](37bf00)Refined schematics[#]() are a upgrade over the normal [#](37bf00)schematics[#](). 
\
\
These [#](37bf00)schematics[#]() don't have any special abilities, but they have slightly better stats than regular tools.

You can find these [#](37bf00)schematics[#]() by exploring the world. Destroy villages and villagers, free bastions, kill pillagers or by being boring and trade your way there. 
\
\
~JorisdeBeer, 2024
book.forgero.guidebook.schematics.extend:
[#](37bf00)Extended schematics[#]() push the boundaries of fantasy and functionality.
\
\
[#](000CFF)Tools[#]() created with these [#](37bf00)schematics[#]() have abilities that are often explained in the tooltip.
[#](37bf00)Extended schematics[#]() can be found by exploring different locations, trading with a traveling villager or obtained as a drop from killing pillagers.
book.forgero.guidebook.schematics.master:
[#](37bf00)Mastercrafted schematics[#]() are a upgrade over the normal and refined [#](37bf00)schematics[#](). 
\
\
Just like the refined ones provide better stats, mastercrafted schematics also feature more [#](FF00C5)slots[#]().

Just like all the other [#](37bf00)schematics[#]() you can find these by exploring the world. 
\
\
These [#](37bf00)schematics[#]() are the most rare of them all. Some blacksmiths never even see these in their lifetime.
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.upgrade:
Customizing your tool is all done with the [#](7C00FF)Upgrade Station[#](). 
\
\
The [#](7C00FF)Upgrade Station[#]() allows you to hotswap materials and certain parts in and out of your [#](000CFF)tools[#]().

The [#](7C00FF)Upgrade Station[#]() is the only way to acces all the [#](FF00C5)slots[#]() on a [#](000CFF)tool[#](). 
\
\
Thus being necessary if you want to dye or alter your [#](000CFF)tools[#]().
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.stats.t: Most stats on tools are straightforward. If you want to get the most out of your [#](000CFF)tools[#]() we suggest watching the tooltip very closely as this gives alot of information.
Weight and Attack speed are a bit of an outlier when looking at the stats on a tool. 
\
\
As a base value every material in Forgero has 2 attack speed, and the weight on the material then decides how much is taken off of the base value.

Next to attack speed weight also has a impact on your hunger bar. 
\
\
The tools weight determines how much you have to eat in order to replenish your hunger.
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.slots.t:
[#](000CFF)Tools[#]() have different [#](FF00C5)slots[#](), and all have their own benefits. Not all materials are viable in every slot, and we highly encourage you to experiment! 
\
\
Think about it, would it make sense to add vines to the tip of your sword?

We categorize the [#](FF00C5)slots[#]() into three main ones.
\
\
So we have Utility, Offensive and Trinket [#](FF00C5)slots[#]().
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.utility: [#](FF00C5)Utility slots[#]() are almost always filled by soft materials. Think of leather, vines and certain mob drops.
Next to just upgrades and materials, these [#](FF00C5)slots[#]() could also house a binding or dyes to customize your [#](000CFF)tool[#]().
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.binding:
Bindings are parts you add to your [#](000CFF)tool[#]() adding durability, speed and maybe even some trinkets down the line.
\
\
There are different types of Bindings. Soft bindings are lighter, and made with less durable material while normal bindings are heavy but more durable.
Just like bindings, pommels are a part upgrade adding durability in exchange for weight.
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.grip.te: The handle grip gives a small bit of durability to your [#](000CFF)tool[#](), and some materials also give stat increases such as additional mining speed or attack speed when used in this [#](FF00C5)slot[#]().
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.cosmeti: Dyes don't add any stats and are purely cosmetic. Think of them as a [#](000CFF)tool[#]() skin similar to other games. However, other upgrades on the tool will always override dyes, so make sure to plan accordingly!
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.trinket: Trinkets exist (currently) only out of gems and can only be added to bindings and guards.
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.gems.te:
Gems add additional base stats to a [#](000CFF)tool[#](). For every stat there is, you have one type of gem that amplifies it. 
\
\
Gems are based on minerals. So for example we have diamond gems, but also lapiz lazuli gems.

Gems can be found while mining. 
\
\
Gems can be upgraded to level 5, and each level increases the modifier it gives. To upgrade you will need to gather some unique materials.
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.offensi: Offensive slots can add attack damage, mining speed or durability, depending on what material you use. Materials that fit here are hard materials such as stone and iron.
book.forgero.guidebook.upgrading.reinfor:
Reinforcements are the backbone of a [#](000CFF)tool[#](). 
\
\
Want your wooden [#](000CFF)tool[#]() to mine diamonds? No? Well you can do that anyways with a bit of netherite!

With the right reinforcements you can add multiple mining levels or increase the mining speed of your [#](000CFF)tool[#](). 
\
\
There is no correct or incorrect combination so it's best to try what works out for you!
